{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3593501,"name":"Andrew Hendricksen","username":"Osheego","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/osheego/{size}/194928_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T23:22:14.010Z","cooked":"

Tired of picking hot glue out of your roboRIO at the end of every season? Introducing 3D printable roboRIO Molex SL locking connector inserts.

Background

Earlier this season Team 100: The Wildhats was looking into using custom PCBs for the roboRIO such as the HoundHat or Kitchen Sink in order to break out roboRIO ports to Molex SL locking connectors in order ensure strong connections while also eliminating the pain of removing hot glue from the roboRIO at the end of the season, make it easier to switch between PWM and DIO ports, and possibility of damaging or shorting the pins. Inspired to create a simpler solution, I designed a set of 3D printable inserts and port covers that interact with the roboRIO to provide a locking solution for female Molex connectors.

Using the Inserts

All of the inserts are designed to easily slide into the roboRIO ports, so while some are able to be seated in position and stay decently securely with a friction fit, I would still recommend that you hot glue the 3D printed inserts to the roboRIO before plugging in Molex connectors. If you do want extra security, you can hot glue the Molex connectors to the inserts which still saves the trouble of digging hot glue out of roboRIO ports.

Additionally, these inserts provide more modularity as instead of having to use electrical tape to cover unused ports with electrical tape, you can simply plug in an unused female Molex housing into any unused roboRIO ports which automatically separated each pin and prevents a metal chip from touching any two pins at once and causing a short. Later on if you decide that you want to use a port, instead of fiddling around with electrical tape, you can just unplug the unused housing and plug into the roboRIO port.

Lastly, these inserts help to prevent bent or damaged pins as they either completely cover the pins or significantly reduce the space around pins so parts, tools, or fingers can’t reach the pins even when there are no connectors or housing plugged in.

Team 100’s Experience

We used these inserts during practice and at our two competitions this season and the only complaint is to remember to hot glue PWM 3D printed insert so it doesn’t come loose. We have had no issues with bent pins or shorting and at the end of the season will have minimal hot glue to remove. Additionally, the interchangeability has served us well as we had some mysterious issues with our magnetic encoders before our first competition and were happy that we easily switched the port the encoder was plugged into.

CAD Files & Printing Suggestions

Here are the .step, .f3d, and .stl files.

I have had success printing these “upside down” on Prusa mk4 with a brim and without supports.

Conclusion

I realize I am posting this a little late for teams to use at champs this weekend but whether or not teams are able to utilize this at champs, I hope this is a resource that teams can use at future competitions.

I also know that these inserts may soon be obsolete with the arrival of a new robot controller coming in the next few years, but maybe this can inspire something similar once the CAD for the new controller comes out.
